title: Cape Town students swarm Parliament over fee increases | Education
text:

Related articles Unity trumps politics in protest movement Fee hikes at universities to be capped at 6%, says Nzimande Students rally the troops for fee uprising CAPE TOWN — Protesting students on Wednesday swarmed Parliament ahead of Finance Minister Nhlanhla Nene’s medium-term budget policy statement.
In an unprecedented development Mr Nene's speech was delayed because of a request by the Economic Freedom Fighters that the the whole budget process be stalled so that extra funding could be provided for higher education to address the demands of protesting university students.
Students from the University of Cape Town‚ Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) and Stellenbosch University, and even those studying through Unisa, gathered in Plein Street to demand the scrapping of fee increases. Chanting students also climbed onto the statue of Louis Botha.
pic "We want Gwede‚ we want Gwede‚" students screamed as police arrived at Parliament’s entrance.
Students do not have a memorandum but insisted Higher Education Minister Blade Nzimande or other members of the Cabinet address them.
Siphokazi Makaula from CPUT said: "We want all fees to be decreased. What we are doing will change the minds of government who is not concerned about us."
Sibusiso Thwala‚ president of the CPUT students’ representative council (SRC)‚ said students around the country had united. He reiterated that they rejected the 6% increase. "We want the minister … to come and engage with students … enough is enough. We are sick and tired of the commodification of education‚" he said.
One UCT student said: "Why not strike? South Africa is a place where there is not education for everyone. The gap between the wealthy and the poor is too vast. How are we going to move forward without an education?"
